choices.text: Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia

questions.text: A G2P1 at 17 weeks presented to the OPD with a BP of 148/90 mmHg. Six hours later, her BP is 142/90 mmHg. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic HTN

 

In pregnancy, the timing of hypertension onset is critical in determining the diagnosis. Chronic hypertension is defined as high blood pressure that is present before pregnancy or that is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's blood pressure readings of 148/90 mmHg and 142/90 mmHg at 17 weeks of gestation indicate hypertension occurring before the 20-week threshold, fitting the definition of chronic hypertension.

 

To confirm chronic hypertension, if the patient's blood pressure remains elevated 12 weeks postpartum, the diagnosis is solidified.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preeclampsia: This is incorrect because preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension that develops after 20 weeks of gestation and is accompanied by proteinuria. This patient's hypertension was noted before 20 weeks and there is no mention of proteinuria.

 

Option B. Gestational HTN: This option is incorrect as gestational hypertension also develops after 20 weeks of gestation. This patient's hypertension was detected at 17 weeks, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia: This is incorrect because superimposed preeclampsia would require evidence of new-onset proteinuria or worsening hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation in a patient with pre-existing chronic hypertension. There is no mention of proteinuria in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation in a pregnant woman is most likely chronic hypertension.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is less then 1 cm dilated and length is 3 cm. The vertex is at -2 station and the cervix is soft and anterior. What will be the bishop score for this lady? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5

 

Explanation:

 

The Bishop's score, in this case, is 5.

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor.
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm).
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:

 

 

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bishop score is used to evaluate the readiness of the cervix for induction of labor. A score of 6 or more suggests that the cervix is favorable for induction.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is usually 6-7 cm. This measurement is essential in gynecological evaluations and procedures.
  • This measurement helps in assessing normal uterine anatomy and can be used in various clinical procedures such as the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Ovary: The ovary measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm.
  • Fallopian Tube: The length of the Fallopian tube is about 10 cm, and the lumen is 1-2 mm at the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is 6-7 cm.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition Pg 25, Dutta's textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 7

choices.text: Left axis deviation
Mild ST changes in inferior leads
Atrial and ventricular premature contractions
Pansystolic murmur

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:

 

  1. Clinical Examination:
    • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
    • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
    • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
    • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
    • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
    • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  2. Electrocardiography:
    • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
    • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
    • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
    • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
    • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
    • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.

 

Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.

 

Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.
  • It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Option C. Ureaplasma urealyticum: Causes urethritis

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Causes syphilis

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with CA cervix. Investigations revealed a lesion of 3.5 cm. What can the appropriate management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 3 hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has CA cervix Stage 1B2 and the management will be Type 3 / Radical hysterectomy.

 

FIGO Revised staging of cervical cancer (2018)

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Type 1: Simple extra fascial hysterectomy

 

Type 2: Modified radical hysterectomy

 

Type3: Radical Hysterectomy

 

Type4: Extended Radical hysterectomy

 

Type 5: Partial Exenteration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 hysterectomy (Simple extra fascial hysterectomy): Suitable for Stage 1A1 (without lymph-vascular space invasion - LVSI) or conization.

 

Option B. Type 2 hysterectomy (Modified radical hysterectomy): Suitable for Stage 1A1 (with LVSI) and Stage 1A2.

 

Option D. Type 4 hysterectomy (Extended radical hysterectomy): Typically used for more advanced stages or extensive disease beyond Stage 1B2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cervical cancer staging, a lesion size between 2 to 4 cm (Stage 1B2) is best managed with a Type 3 (Radical) hysterectomy.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynaecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology 8th edition page367

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.text: A pregnant female with known cardiac disease presents in the first trimester with history of warfarin embryopathy. What should be advised now? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

 

Warfarin readily crosses the placenta and is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when exposure occurs between the 6th and 9th weeks of pregnancy. Warfarin embryopathy is characterized by stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia.

 

Management guidelines for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves requiring anticoagulation:

 

  • First trimester: Women on warfarin should be switched to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed to avoid teratogenic effects.
  • Second and third trimesters (13 to 36 weeks): Warfarin can be resumed as it is the most effective anticoagulant in preventing thromboembolic events.
  • Near delivery: Warfarin should be switched back to heparin around delivery to avoid complications. Heparin should be stopped prior to delivery.

 

Mechanical heart valves: Require lifelong anticoagulation, whereas bioprosthetic valves do not require lifelong anticoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin throughout the pregnancy: Continuing warfarin throughout the pregnancy is not advisable due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy and potential fetal hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Give accoumarin: Accoumarin is not a standard recommendation for anticoagulation in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option D. Use LMW heparin: While low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is safer in pregnancy compared to warfarin, the specific recommendation is to switch to heparin in the first trimester and possibly back to warfarin in the second and third trimesters, depending on individual risk assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with mechanical heart valves on warfarin, switch to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed in the first trimester to avoid teratogenic effects, and manage anticoagulation carefully throughout the pregnancy to minimize risks to both mother and fetus.

 

 

Algorithm for management of women with prosthetic heart valves requiring anti-coagulation in pregnancy

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2406

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Septate uterus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anomaly seen in the given hysterosalpingogram is suggestive of a septate uterus.
  • A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts
  • On HSG, a septate and bicornuate uterus are commonly mis-diagnosed
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is <75, it is likely a septate uterus (As in this question)
  • If the angle between the 2 horns is >105, then it is likely a bicornuate uterus
  • However, an HSG is not the ideal ix of choice
  • An MRI is the best Ix for Mullerian anomalies

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine didelphys: Uterine didelphys appears as 2 completely separate uterine cavities on the HSG with no communication whatsoever

 

 

Option C. Bicornuate uterus: Bicornuate uterus: This appears as 2 horns of the uterus which are widely separated (angle > 105 degree)

 

 

Option D. Unicornuate uterus: Unicornuate uterus: Single horn on the HSG

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anomaly seen in the image is a septate uterus which is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity which hasn’t disappeared after fusion of the 2 Mullerian ducts.

 

Ref: Page 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estrogen

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, the granulosa cells of the developing follicles secrete high amounts of estrogen, specifically estradiol. This phase is characterized by the development of a primordial follicle to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles. The following events occur during this phase:

 

  • Estrogen Secretion: Granulosa cells secrete increasing amounts of estrogen, primarily estradiol, which causes proliferation of the endometrium in preparation for potential implantation.
  • Up-regulation of Receptors: LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in both theca and granulosa cells.
  • Feedback Mechanism: The rising estradiol levels exert a negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary, suppressing the secretion of FSH and LH to moderate levels.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles but is not secreted by granulosa cells.

 

Option C. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and plays a role in the later stages of follicle development and ovulation.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum after ovulation during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, ovarian granulosa cells secrete high amounts of estrogen, which is crucial for the proliferation of the endometrium and regulation of FSH and LH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 78, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Karyotyping of the parents

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic sonography

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause of recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound (pelvic sonography) as it is non-invasive and provides detailed imaging of the uterine structure.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Recurrent first trimester abortions: Often associated with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) or endocrinological causes.
  • Recurrent second trimester abortions: Often associated with anatomical uterine problems.
  • Single spontaneous abortion: Most commonly caused by fetal genetic abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hysterosalpingography: This is not routinely advised for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. It is more commonly used for evaluating tubal patency and uterine cavity shape but is not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Endometrial Biopsy: This is advised in women with suspected genital tuberculosis or in women with suspected luteal phase defect. It is not typically indicated for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss.

 

Option D. Karyotyping of the parents: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as balanced translocations, account for only about 5% of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Therefore, parental karyotyping is not an initial investigation of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is pelvic sonography to evaluate for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 2t6h edition pg 203

questions.text: Which hormone is increased in the condition shown in the image?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the classic "snowstorm" appearance seen on ultrasound, which is characteristic of a molar pregnancy, specifically a complete mole. In a complete molar pregnancy, there is abnormal trophoblastic proliferation and hydropic degeneration of chorionic villi, leading to the absence of fetal tissue and the characteristic ultrasound appearance.

 

The key hormone that is markedly elevated in molar pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). This hormone is produced in excessive amounts due to the trophoblastic proliferation. The extremely high levels of hCG are responsible for many of the symptoms and complications associated with molar pregnancies, such as hyperemesis gravidarum, early-onset preeclampsia, and ovarian theca-lutein cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): This hormone is involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and ovulation but is not specifically elevated in molar pregnancy.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Levels of estrogen can be altered in pregnancy and other conditions but are not specifically elevated in molar pregnancy.

 

Option D. Progesterone: This hormone supports pregnancy, but its levels are not specifically elevated due to molar pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hormone significantly elevated in molar pregnancy, as indicated by the ultrasound image showing a "snowstorm" appearance, is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose unicornuate uterus?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Falloposcopy
  2. Laparoscopy
  3. HSG
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

2. Laparoscopy: This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, including the uterus. It is effective in diagnosing structural anomalies like a unicornuate uterus.

 

3. HSG (Hysterosalpingogram): This is an X-ray procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It helps in visualizing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, making it useful in diagnosing a unicornuate uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 4: While laparoscopy (2) is correct, X-ray (4) alone is not specific or detailed enough to diagnose a unicornuate uterus.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Falloposcopy (1) is used to visualize the interior of the fallopian tubes, not to diagnose uterine anomalies. Laparoscopy (2) is correct but falloposcopy is not appropriate for this diagnosis.

 

Option C. 1, 3: Similar to option B, falloposcopy (1) is not relevant for diagnosing uterine anomalies, even though HSG (3) is correct.

 

  • Falloposcopy: Refers to the visualization of the interior of the fallopian tube lumen and tubal ostia using a flexible fiber optic device via hysteroscope.
  • Diagnosis of Mullerian Anomalies: Can be achieved through various methods, including:
    1. Ultrasound (Preferably 3D USG)
    2. MRI (Investigation of choice)
    3. HSG
    4. Hystero-laparoscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy and HSG are effective diagnostic tools for identifying unicornuate uterus and other Mullerian anomalies.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 47, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg418

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: IUCD can be inserted after delivery till? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 48hrs


An Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD), specifically the Copper T, can be inserted immediately after delivery as part of postpartum family planning. The optimal time frames for insertion include:

 

  1. Post-placental insertion: Within 10 minutes of placental delivery, commonly done when the patient is highly motivated.
  2. Early postpartum insertion: From 10 minutes up to 48 hours after delivery.
  3. Intra-caesarean insertion: At the time of cesarean section.
  4. Late postpartum – After 6 weeks 

 

Early postpartum IUCD insertion is considered safe and effective during this period due to the lower risk of expulsion and higher motivation of the patient.

 

Note -  48hrs to 6 weeks’ period is not suitable for IUCD insertion due to the high risk of expulsion and complications as the uterus is actively involuting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery, but not between 48 hours to 6 weeks due to the high risk of expulsion during this time.

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with human gonadotropin. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

 

  • The image is a transvaginal ultrasound showing the ovaries which appear significantly enlarged with fluid in the pelvic cavity (the black spaces seen in between the ovaries)
  • In view of her history of controlled ovarian hyperstimulation in IVF, the answer is OHSS
    • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability and leakage of intravascular fluid to the third space.
    • It is commonly seen after exogenous administration of FSH, LH or HCG injections.
    • Multiple enlarged follicles are arranged in a necklace pattern in bilateral ovaries.
    • The mainstay of management is conservative. The ongoing stimulation cycle is suspended, and further administration of exogenous gonadotropins are stopped in that cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Theca lutein cysts: Enlarged cysts seen in molar pregnancy, not related to the provided scenario or ultrasound findings.

 

Option C. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a risk factor for OHSS, but given the history and the ultrasound image, OHSS is the more appropriate answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OHSS is characterized by multiple enlarged ovarian follicles and fluid accumulation in the pelvic cavity, often occurring after exogenous gonadotropin administration in infertility treatments.

 

Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: According to the latest labour care guidelines, the partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 cm

 

  • Earlier, in the WHO modified partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In this partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele's rule? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) October 16

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day 
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 9 months and subtract 7 days from the date of the embryo transfer
  • For e.g. The EDD of this patient will be 16/10/2017.
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND.
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naegele's rule is a standard way of calculating the estimated date of delivery by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period. This method assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 83, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased number of theca lutein cysts

 

Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) that arises from trophoblastic tissue following a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, abortion, or normal pregnancy. Indicators of choriocarcinoma include:

 

  • Persistently enlarged uterus: Indicates continued trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Plateau of high serum hCG: Persistent high levels of hCG after treatment suggest ongoing trophoblastic disease.
  • Sub-urethral nodule: A rare but specific sign of metastatic choriocarcinoma.

 

The presence of theca lutein cysts alone is not a specific indicator of choriocarcinoma, though these cysts can persist in cases of GTN. The increased number of theca lutein cysts is associated with molar pregnancies and persistent GTN but not specifically indicative of choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Persistently enlarged uterus: This is a common finding in choriocarcinoma due to persistent trophoblastic tissue.

 

Option C. Plateau of high serum hCG: This is a hallmark of choriocarcinoma as it indicates continued activity of the trophoblastic cells.

 

Option D. Sub-urethral nodule: This can be a sign of metastasis from choriocarcinoma. Indicates metastasis of choriocarcinoma forming a firm palpable mass beneath urethral nodule

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indicators of choriocarcinoma include persistently enlarged uterus, plateau of high serum hCG, and sub-urethral nodules, but not an increased number of theca lutein cysts alone.

 

Ref: Page no 361, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Genital Tuberculosis

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, difficulty in walking and sitting. She has a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, a tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin abscess

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image points to the diagnosis of Bartholin's abscess.

 

Bartholin Cyst and Abscess

 

Bartholin gland is a mucus-secreting gland, which plays a role in vaginal lubrication. They are a pair of 0.5 cm glands located in the lower right and left portions at the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal introitus. They are generally nonpalpable when not obstructed.

 

Pathophysiology: Bartholin glands can form a cyst and an abscess in women of reproductive age and may cause dyspareunia, urinary irritation, and vague pelvic pain.

 

C/F:

 

  • The physical exam will often reveal asymmetry with a protrusion of one side (left or right) of the inferior aspect of the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland abscesses, unlike Bartholin cysts, are very painful.
  • While both are primarily unilateral, Bartholin abscesses are often tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, and may have an area of fluctuance and/or purulent drainage.
  • Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Bartholin cysts do not require further treatment.
  • Bartholin abscesses may be treated with incision and drainage with Word catheter placement due to ease and effectiveness of treatment.
  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice.
  • Women with recurrent cysts or those who are post-menopausal (risk of malignancy) should have the cyst completely excised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chlamydial infection: Chlamydial infection patient usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, or cervicitis.

 

Option C. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis involves the upper genital tract, leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Genital herpes usually presents as painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital area, rather than a tender, erythematous swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin abscess presents with significant pain, redness, and swelling in the labia, often making walking and sitting difficult.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive of choice in a 28-week preeclamptic woman with asthma? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Explanation:

 

In managing preeclampsia, labetalol is often the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy. However, labetalol is both an alpha and beta-blocker, and its use can exacerbate asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Therefore, it is contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Nifedipine: This is a calcium channel blocker that is safe and effective in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of labetalol, making it the antihypertensive of choice for a preeclamptic woman with asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral labetalol and Option B. IV labetalol: Both forms are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: This angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause fetal renal hypoperfusion and oligohydramnios, among other teratogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine is the antihypertensive of choice in a preeclamptic woman with asthma due to its safety profile and lack of broncho constrictive effects.

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

choices.text: 6 to 10 weeks
8 to 12 weeks
13 to 20 weeks
20 to 28 weeks

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 13 to 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) is a double-stranded DNA virus that is primarily acquired in childhood and causes chickenpox. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with an infected individual. Nonimmune pregnant women who come into close contact with a patient with chickenpox are at risk of contracting the infection.

 

If a pregnant woman contracts chickenpox, particularly early in pregnancy, there is a risk of congenital varicella syndrome in the fetus. The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome is between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Congenital varicella syndrome includes the following features:

 

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

 

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active VZV infection just before or during delivery (less than 5 days before and up to 2 days after delivery), there is a significant risk of disseminated disease and CNS involvement in the neonate, with a mortality rate of approximately 30%. In such cases, administration of VZIG (Varicella-Zoster Immune Globulin) is recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest risk period for the development of congenital varicella syndrome in a fetus is when the mother is infected with Varicella Zoster Virus between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 3085

choices.text: POP for 3 months

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

Explanation:

 

The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is an endometrial biopsy. This is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, especially in a peri-menopausal woman.

 

Indications for Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Peri-menopausal women with AUB.
  • Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS).
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.

 

Methods of Endometrial Sampling:

 

  • Curettage
  • Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LNG-IUCD: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD) is a treatment option but should be considered after ruling out malignancy.

 

Option B. POP for 3 months: Progestin-only pills (POP) can be used to manage AUB, but endometrial sampling should be done first to rule out malignancy.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is considered after other management options and ruling out malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In peri-menopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to perform endometrial sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before considering other treatment modalities.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg184

choices.text: Non vigorous baby
Rh negative mother

questions.text: When should early cord clamping be done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non vigorous baby

 

Early cord clamping should be done primarily when the baby is non-vigorous/ hypoxic baby i.e. not breathing, or not crying at birth. Immediate neonatal resuscitation is required in such cases to address the baby's urgent need for oxygen and support.

 

Delaying cord clamping in a non-vigorous baby could waste crucial time needed for resuscitation efforts. According to WHO guidelines, the only absolute contraindication to delayed cord clamping is a non-vigorous baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rh negative mother: Although older guidelines suggested early cord clamping in Rh-negative mothers to reduce the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhage, current guidelines do not strongly recommend this practice. The benefits of delayed cord clamping, such as reducing anemia in the baby, outweigh the potential risks.

 

Option C. Preterm: For preterm babies, delayed cord clamping is recommended to help prevent anemia and improve blood volume. Preterm infants benefit significantly from the additional blood received during delayed clamping.

 

Option D. Pre-eclampsia: Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for delayed cord clamping. Delayed clamping can still provide the newborn with additional blood and help prevent anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early cord clamping is indicated for non-vigorous babies who require immediate resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

 

  • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.

 

Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify this maneuver: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ritgen maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the Ritgen maneuver, which is performed during the second stage of labor to control the delivery of the fetal head. This maneuver involves controlled extension of the head to minimize perineal trauma. The pressure is applied on the fetal chin through the perineum while simultaneously controlling the speed of delivery of the head with the other hand.

 

This helps in a gradual delivery of the head, reducing the risk of severe perineal tears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinard maneuver: This maneuver is used during breech delivery to assist in delivering the legs by hooking them at the popliteal fossa.

 

 

Option B. Lovset maneuver: This is also used in breech delivery, specifically to help deliver the arms that are positioned over the head (nuchal arms).

 

 

Option D. Mauriceau maneuver: This is used for delivering the after-coming head in a breech presentation, involving the application of pressure on the maxilla and supporting the body of the baby to facilitate head delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ritgen maneuver involves controlled extension of the fetal head during delivery to minimize perineal trauma and ensure a smooth birth process.

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 – 30% of the dose to point A (4500 – 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: What is true regarding normal semen parameters? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Motility >32%

 

Explanation:

 

According to the recent guidelines on normal semen parameters, progressive motility should be more than 32%. This is an important indicator of sperm health and fertility potential. The motility of sperm refers to their ability to move efficiently, which is crucial for natural conception as the sperm must travel through the female reproductive tract to fertilize the egg.

 

Other Options:

 

The other parameters provided in the options are either outdated or incorrect according to the latest guidelines:

 

Option B. Sperm count > 20 million: The current guideline indicates that the sperm count should be more than 16 million per milliliter, not 20 million.

 

Option C. Morphology < 8%: The normal morphology (shape and structure) of sperm should be more than 4%, not less than 8%. This means that at least 4% of the sperm should have a normal shape.

 

Option D. Sperm concentration < 40 million/ml: The correct parameter is that sperm concentration should be more than 16 million per milliliter, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational objective:

 

The correct parameter for normal semen analysis regarding motility is that progressive motility should be more than 32%.

questions.text: The given instrument is used in: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The instrument shown is a Doyen's retractor, which is specifically used in cesarean sections. It plays a crucial role during the surgical procedure by retracting the bladder to provide proper exposure of the lower uterine segment. This retraction helps in ensuring a clear view and access to the uterus while minimizing the risk of bladder injury. The Doyen's retractor is used once the utero-vesical fold of peritoneum is opened and the bladder is dissected away from the lower uterine segment. It holds the bladder away from the site of the uterine incision, facilitating a safer and more efficient cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Involves the removal of the uterus through the vaginal canal and typically uses different types of retractors and instruments designed for vaginal access, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Option C. Manchester operation: This is a surgical procedure used to correct uterovaginal prolapse and does not involve the use of Doyen's retractor.

 

Option D. Fothergill's surgery: This is performed for uterovaginal prolapse and uses different instruments tailored for vaginal repairs, not the Doyen's retractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doyen's retractor is used during cesarean sections to retract the bladder and prevent bladder injury while providing exposure of the lower uterine segment.

 

Ref: Page no 751, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman whose last delivery was 5 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea of 2 years. She does not bleed on giving estrogen and progesterone. A laparoscopy shows the following. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital TB

 

The patient presents with secondary amenorrhea for two years and does not bleed when given estrogen and progesterone, indicating that the problem lies in the endometrium. The destruction of the endometrium can occur due to two main conditions: Asherman's syndrome and genital tuberculosis.

 

  • Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions typically following a vigorous dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Genital tuberculosis, however, causes chronic endometritis, leading to the destruction of the endometrium and the absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. The laparoscopy shows whitish caseating lesions on the surface of the uterus, which are characteristic of genital tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causing pelvic pain and infertility. It does not typically result in secondary amenorrhea or the absence of bleeding on hormone administration, and it does not produce the characteristic whitish lesions seen in the laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Fibroids: Uterine fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can cause menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, and pain but do not lead to secondary amenorrhea or absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. Fibroids also do not present with caseating lesions.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that rarely affects the genital tract. It does not cause endometrial destruction, secondary amenorrhea, or the absence of withdrawal bleeding when given hormones, nor does it produce the characteristic uterine lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis can cause chronic endometritis and endometrial destruction, leading to secondary amenorrhea and absence of withdrawal bleeding on hormone administration, with characteristic whitish caseating lesions visible on laparoscopy.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right occipito-anterior

 

The Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position means the fetal occiput (the back of the head) is directed towards the mother's right side and anterior (towards the front of the pelvis). This position indicates that the fetus is facing towards the mother's right side with its back towards the front of the pelvis.

 

In fetal positions:

 

  • Right occipito-anterior (ROA): The occiput is on the right side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-anterior (LOA): The occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.
  • Right occipito-posterior (ROP): The occiput is on the right side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.
  • Left occipito-posterior (LOP): The occiput is on the left side but posteriorly towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Right occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the right side but towards the back of the pelvis, not the front.

 

Option B. Left occipito-anterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side and anteriorly towards the front of the pelvis.

 

Option C. Left occipito-posterior: This position indicates that the occiput is on the left side but towards the back of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Right occipito-anterior (ROA) position, the fetal occiput is directed towards the mother's right side and the anterior part of the pelvis.

 

Ref: Page 89, DC Ditta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Y chromosome

 

Explanation:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene located on the short arm of the Y chromosome. The SRY gene produces testis-determining factor (TDF), which induces the development of the bipotential gonads into testes. The Sertoli cells in the testes secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), which causes regression of the Mullerian ducts, structures that would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene, which leads to the secretion of Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) by the Sertoli cells and regression of the Mullerian ducts in males.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manuever and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

A vaginal pessary is a device used to support the pelvic organs in women with uterovaginal prolapse who are either unfit for surgery or unwilling to undergo surgery. The fitting process involves several steps to ensure the pessary is comfortable and effective:

 

  1. Patient Preparation: The patient is positioned in the lithotomy position and should have an empty bladder and rectum.
  2. Vaginal Examination: An assessment of vaginal length and width is performed to estimate the appropriate pessary size.
  3. Insertion: The pessary is lubricated and inserted in a cephalad direction against the posterior vaginal wall.
  4. Placement Check: An index finger is directed into the posterior vaginal fornix to ensure the cervix is above the pessary, and the pessary should fit snugly against the vaginal walls without causing pain.
  5. Adequacy Check: The patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver (forceful exhalation against a closed airway) to see if the pessary remains in place, ensuring it is not dislodged during increased intra-abdominal pressure.
  6. Functionality Check: The patient should be able to stand, walk, cough, and urinate without difficulty or discomfort.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: While checking the ability to void is important, it is not the first step after fitting the pessary.

 

Option B. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Patient comfort is crucial, but discomfort does not necessarily mean the pessary is adequately retained.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard method for checking the fit of a pessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After fitting a pessary, the first step to check if it is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary remains in place.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

questions.text: At what period of gestation is the nuchal translucency measured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement is an ultrasound marker used for the screening of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The optimal time to measure NT is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, more specifically between 11 weeks and 13 weeks and 6 days. During this period, the NT measurement is most accurate and predictive. The NT scan involves measuring the clear space in the tissue at the back of the baby's neck.

 

An absent Nasal Bone (NB) and increased NT measurement both are the marker of Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Nuchal translucency should be measured between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation to effectively screen for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text: Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CAD Prophylaxis

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not recommended for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Although there was some belief in the past that HRT might provide cardiovascular benefits, extensive research has shown that HRT does not prevent CAD and may, in fact, increase the risk of certain cardiovascular events in some women.

 

HRT is primarily indicated for the management of symptoms associated with menopause and for certain therapeutic and prophylactic uses:

 

Therapeutic Indications:

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Premature ovarian failure
  • Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms)
  • Vaginal dryness

 

Prophylactic Indications:

 

  • Prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women

 

Risks of HRT:

 

  • Increased risk of endometrial cancer (particularly with unopposed estrogen in women with an intact uterus)
  • Increased risk of breast cancer
  • Increased risk of ovarian cancer
  • Increased risk of thromboembolism
  • Possible adverse effects on lipid profiles
  • Increased risk of gallstones and liver dysfunction

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot flashes: HRT is widely used to manage hot flashes and other vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause. It is one of the most effective treatments for these symptoms.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: HRT is used prophylactically to prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women by maintaining bone density and reducing the risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Premature menopause: Women experiencing premature menopause or premature ovarian failure can benefit from HRT to manage symptoms and reduce the long-term risks associated with early loss of estrogen, including osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for the prophylaxis of coronary artery disease (CAD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 61,62

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to OPD with complaint of greenish-frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month. Examination revealed finding as shown in image. On saline microscopy, motile organisms are noticed. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image showing strawberry cervix, is suggestive of Trichomoniasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial Vaginosis

 

  • Discharge: White, thin, homogenous with a foul odor.
  • Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria - clue cells on wet mount, whiff test positive, pH > 4.5, homogenous discharge.
  • Symptoms: Usually no erythema or significant irritation.

 

Option C. Chlamydial Cervicitis

 

  • Typically associated with mucopurulent cervical discharge and may not present with frothy discharge or a strawberry cervix.
  • Diagnosis: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are used to detect Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Option D. Candidiasis

 

  • Discharge: Thick, curdy white with no odor.
  • Diagnosis: KOH prep revealing pseudohyphae or spores, wet mount.
  • Symptoms: Pruritis and dysuria with notable erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomoniasis is characterized by greenish-frothy vaginal discharge, a strawberry cervix, and motile organisms on saline microscopy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Gynaecology 6th edition page 166

choices.text: Parvovirus
Toxoplasma
HIV

questions.text: Which of these is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus

 

  • Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis. (Non immune hydrops)
  • Parvovirus B19 infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells and causes anemia.
  • Severe anemia leads to high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. CMV: Typically causes peri-ventricular calcifications in the fetus.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Causes:  hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification, microcephaly, seizures and mental retardation in the newborn.

 

Option D. HIV: Vertical transmission of HIV from mother to infant can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis due to its effect on fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to severe anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure.

 

Ref: Page no 347, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that there is cord prolapse. What should be the next immediate step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put her in Trendelenburg position

 

Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus in the birth canal, leading to compression of the cord. This compression can restrict blood flow and oxygen to the fetus, causing fetal distress or hypoxia.

 

The immediate management of cord prolapse includes:

 

  • Relieving pressure off the cord: This is crucial to prevent fetal hypoxia. This can be achieved by positioning the patient in a way that minimizes pressure on the cord.
  • Trendelenburg position: This position involves tilting the patient’s body with the head down and the pelvis up. This helps to shift the fetal presenting part off the prolapsed cord and relieves compression.
  • Left lateral position or All-fours position: Alternative positions can also help in relieving pressure on the cord.

 

While preparing for an emergency cesarean section (LSCS) to deliver the fetus urgently, these positions and techniques are used to temporarily alleviate the pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gently replace the cord inside the vagina: Attempting to reposition the cord is not recommended as it can cause further damage or spasm of the vessels in the cord.

 

Option B. Inform the doctor and shift to OT: While informing the doctor and preparing for cesarean delivery is necessary, immediate steps to relieve cord compression should be taken first.

 

Option D. Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation: This may be done, but the primary focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord immediately to prevent fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of cord prolapse, placing the patient in Trendelenburg position helps to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a critical step in managing the emergency until a cesarean section can be performed.

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G4P1 A2 L1

 

Determining the Parity Index/ Obstetric Formula

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

The obstetric score here is G4P1A2L1.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2.
