questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba → Lochia Rubra
Lochia Serosa → Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba
Lochia Rubra → Lochia Alba → Lochia Serosa

questions.text: Mark the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium: (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lochia Rubra → Lochia Serosa → Lochia Alba

 

Explanation:

 

Lochia is vaginal discharge after delivery.

 

It is composed of sloughed off decidua, blood, necrotic debris and secretions of the cervixand vagina.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of lochia during the puerperium is Lochia Rubra (red, first 3-4 days), Lochia Serosa (yellowish-brownish, 5-9 days), and Lochia Alba (white, lasts 10-28 days).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic with a normal hysterosalpingogram and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following test is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular Biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The absence of sperm in semen is known as azoospermia. It can be due to:
    • Pre-testicular azoospermia due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • Testicular failure or non-obstructive azoospermia
    • Post-testicular obstruction implies normal spermatogenesis but failure to deliver the sperm into the ejaculate because of ducal obstruction.
  • In testicular cause of azoospermia, there will be absent or very few sperms on biopsy whereas in obstructive azoospermia, there will be normal sperms on biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum FSH levels and Option B. Serum testosterone levels are important for spermatogenesis

 

  • FSH levels can be used to differentiate hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism from other causes of testicular failure

 

Option D. Serum LH level: LH is a non-specific test in evaluation of azoospermia

 

Educational Objective:

 

A testicular biopsy is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of Azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 233, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6the edition

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, ovarian drilling is beneficial? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Management of PCOS typically starts lifestyle modification.  Medical management with metformin (for insulin resistance) and then depending on the symptoms that a patient presents with such as irregular menses (OC pills, Progesterone), hirsuitism (cyproterone acetate, Spironolactone) or infertility (Oral Ovulogens such as letrozole, clomiphene) may be considered.

 

Ovarian drilling is NOT a first-line treatment and may be considered in resistant cases.

 

LAPAROSCOPIC OVARIAN DRILLING

 

  • Small holes are made in follicles to resume ovulation in women who are not responding to drugs.
  • Advantage: induce the resumption of ovulation in more than 50% females
  • Disadvantages: invasive procedure, can cause adhesion.
  • 4 drills should be done in each ovary. Depth of 4mm for 4 seconds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian tumour: Treatment would generally involve laparotomy or laparoscopy  for surgical excision depending on various factors such as whether benign or malignant, size of tumour , staging etc

 

Option C. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome:  It occurs as a complication of ovarian stimulation used in ART procedures characterized by enlarged ovaries and third space fluid loss due to increased capillary permeability progressing to ascites, pleural effusion. It is managed conservatively.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: It is characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrium in locations other than the endometrial lining. Treatment may be conservative medical management or surgical excision of the endometriotic lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology page471

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

 

The correct answer is MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic). The classification of twin pregnancies is based on the timing of the zygote's division and the resulting structures, such as the number of chorions (placentas) and amnions (amniotic sacs) that form.

 

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins occur when the division happens very early (within the first 72 hours after fertilization), resulting in two separate chorions and amnions.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA) twins occur when the division happens between the 4th and 8th day after fertilization, after the chorion has formed but before the amniotic sac has split.
  • Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins result from division that occurs between the 9th and 12th day after fertilization, after both the chorion and amnion have formed, leading to two embryos sharing a single amniotic sac and a single chorion.
  • Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible scenario. The formation of a single amnion with two separate chorions (placentas) does not occur because the chorion forms before the amnion. Thus, this combination is anatomically and developmentally impossible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. MCMA (Monochorionic Monoamniotic): This is a recognized type of twin pregnancy where twins share both the chorion and the amnion.

 

Option B. MCDA (Monochorionic Diamniotic): Another recognized type, where twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. DADC (Dichorionic Diamniotic): This is the most common type of twin pregnancy, especially in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, where each twin has its own chorion and amnion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia
Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia
Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.

 

Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:

 

Angiogenic Factors:

 

  • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased
    • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
    • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • Factors that are decreased are
    • PlGF
    • PAPP-A
    • VEGF

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).

 

Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Premature ovarian failure
Delayed blood transfusion reaction

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Sheehan syndrome:

 

  • The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation, is Sheehan syndrome.
  • Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage.
  • The history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates significant blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia leading to this condition.
  • Symptoms such as fatiguability and constipation can be attributed to secondary hypothyroidism resulting from pituitary dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: While hypothyroidism can cause fatiguability and constipation, the history of postpartum amenorrhea and lactational failure makes Sheehan syndrome more likely. In Sheehan syndrome, hypothyroidism is a secondary consequence of pituitary dysfunction.

 

Option C. Premature ovarian failure: Premature ovarian failure typically presents with symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness, along with amenorrhea. However, it does not account for the history of significant postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Delayed blood transfusion reaction: Delayed blood transfusion reactions usually present with symptoms such as jaundice, fever, and anemia, but they do not explain the chronic symptoms of fatiguability, constipation, lactational failure, and amenorrhea in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is characterized by panhypopituitarism due to pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage, leading to symptoms such as lactational failure, amenorrhea, fatiguability, and constipation.

 

Ref: Page no 465, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.

 

Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: The daughter of a woman who received diethylstilbestrol during her pregnancy is at higher risk for? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was previously prescribed to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and other pregnancy complications. It was later discovered to be a teratogen and is no longer used.
  • Exposure to DES in utero is known to cause the following conditions:
    • In girls:
      • T-shaped uterus
      • Cockscomb cervix
      • Vaginal and cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma
    • In boys:
      • Micropenis
      • Hypospadias
      • Undescended testes

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of cervical cancer. It arises from the ectocervix, at the squamocolumnar junction. This type of cancer is not specifically associated with DES exposure.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma arises from the endocervix and is not specifically linked to DES exposure.

 

Option D. Sarcoma botryoides: Sarcoma botryoides is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that arises from the cervix. It presents as a pinkish polypoidal growth filling up the vagina completely and causes blood-tinged watery discharge. It is not associated with DES exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DES exposure in utero is specifically associated with an increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg42
